title: 114_hr2901
content: The "Flood Insurance Market Parity and Modernization Act" may be cited as the short title. It pertains to private flood insurance. The Flood Insurance Market Parity and Modernization Act requires that no federal assistance for acquisition or construction in flood hazard areas can be approved without flood insurance coverage after sixty days of enactment. The Flood Insurance Market Parity and Modernization Act mandates that federal assistance for acquisition or construction in flood hazard areas cannot be approved without adequate flood insurance coverage. The required amount of flood insurance must be equal to the development or project cost, outstanding loan balance, or maximum limit of coverage available, depending on the type of insurance. The Flood Insurance Market Parity and Modernization Act mandates that federal assistance for acquisition or construction in flood hazard areas cannot be approved without adequate flood insurance coverage. The amount of flood insurance required for a loan is based on the outstanding principal balance and must be maintained for the life of the property, regardless of ownership transfer. Federal lending institutions must comply with the requirement for mortgage loans under the Flood Disaster Protection Act of 1973. The Financial Institutions Examination Council directs regulated lending institutions to require flood insurance for loans secured by real estate in flood hazard areas identified by the Administrator. Flood insurance must cover the outstanding loan balance for the term of the loan. Federal agency lenders must ensure that flood insurance for loans secured by improved real estate or mobile homes in special flood hazard areas is either equal to the outstanding loan balance or the maximum limit of Federal flood insurance coverage, whichever is less. Private flood insurance must also meet these requirements. Federal agency lenders are required to accept flood insurance as satisfaction for the coverage requirement if it meets specific criteria. Regulations must be issued to ensure compliance with this requirement. The Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation must ensure that loans secured by properties in flood hazard areas have flood insurance coverage under the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968. The building or mobile home and any personal property securing the loan must have flood insurance coverage for the term of the loan. The Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation will accept flood insurance that meets their requirements, ensuring financial strength of private insurance companies. State requirements will not conflict with this. The Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994 specifies that State laws on insurance regulation should not conflict with federal requirements for flood insurance coverage on loans. The Act applies to existing coverage upon enactment and new coverage after a one-year period from enactment. The Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994 mandates that State insurance laws must align with federal flood insurance requirements for loans. Regulations for lenders supervised by the Farm Credit Administration must comply with the Act, with existing regulations remaining in effect until updated regulations are implemented. References to flood insurance in the Act encompass both Federal and private flood insurance. The Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994 requires State insurance laws to align with federal flood insurance requirements for loans. Regulations for lenders supervised by the Farm Credit Administration must comply with the Act, with existing regulations remaining until updated. References to flood insurance include both Federal and private options. In this section, flood insurance is defined as Federal flood insurance and private flood insurance. Federal flood insurance refers to policies under the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968, while private flood insurance is issued by approved insurance companies. Private flood insurance can be provided by insurance companies approved by the state regulator where the insured building is located or by nonadmitted insurers eligible to provide insurance in the insured's home state. The insurance company issuing the policy must not be disapproved as a surplus. Private flood insurance must be provided by an approved insurance company in the state where the property is located and must comply with state laws and regulations. The insurer must not be disapproved as a surplus lines insurer by the state regulator. Private flood insurance coverage can be considered as continuous coverage for statutory requirements, including under section 1307(g)(1). The House of Representatives passed the bill on April 28, 2016.
